student_input: What precedents exist for this type of project?
agent_response:
To design a hotel in Greece inspired by Greek temples, focus on key architectural elements such as columns, pediments, and symmetry. Consider how these can be adapted to enhance flexibility and user experience. For instance, use columns to create open, airy spaces that allow for natural lighting and good circulation. Integrate pediments as decorative elements to maintain a visual connection to traditional Greek architecture. Ensure accessibility by designing wide, welcoming entrances and pathways. Engage the community by incorporating spaces that can host local events, fostering a sense of connection. By blending these historical elements with modern functionality, your hotel can offer both aesthetic appeal and practical benefits.

**Sources:**
• [Architectural Guidelines: Precedents For Greek Temple Inspired Architecture](https://www.dezeen.com/architecture/)

How does incorporating Greek temple-inspired architecture influence the spatial experience and functionality of your hotel design in Greece?

student_input: this is very helpful, are there any other references of projects available? perhaps a different source that is not dezeen?
agent_response:
To find references on Greek temple-inspired architecture for your hotel project in Greece, consider exploring platforms like ArchDaily, Architectural Record, and Domus. These sources offer diverse perspectives on architectural design. Focus on key principles such as flexibility and user experience, ensuring spaces are adaptable and maintain good circulation. Look for projects that incorporate natural lighting and engage with the community, as these elements are crucial in creating inviting and functional spaces. Additionally, explore academic journals and books on classical architecture for deeper insights into Greek temple design. This approach will provide a well-rounded understanding and inspiration for your project.

**Sources:**
• [Architectural Guidelines: References And Sources](https://www.dezeen.com/architecture/)
